group_1.textLeft: If anything, you've changed a lot.@You've become incredibly gentle and calm.

group_1.textRight: I know. I can't help but wonder@how it happened.
I don't lash out at you like I did in the past, and I no@longer argue with you without listening to you first.
I've changed so much that my past self, who was so@fixated on how other people saw us, seems shallow.
But even so, in the past, we were more in tune@with each other, despite how much we fought.
I loved you more than I hated you...!

group_1.textLeft: Still, a change like this can't be undone.

group_1.textRight: How can you be so calm when so much of me@has changed...?!

group_1.textLeft: Because I know why it happened.

group_1.textRight: What...? What caused this?!

group_1.textLeft: A Magical Girl's wish.

group_1.narration: I realized that my parents were@far more deeply intertwined than I knew.

In my narrow perspective, I saw only@two people who were at odds with each other.@I judged one of them as evil and the other as unhappy,@and without having seen their true, beautiful forms,@I destroyed them both.
Perhaps my mother had been balancing@my father's overly laidback attitude when it@came to education...
Yes. I'm certain that was it.
If it weren't for her, I would have been a wild,@impetuous child with no passions or skills.
If I had strove to look at my parents@at different angles, I could have seen@better sides of them and realized the truth@of how they both felt.
It's all my fault.@I made shallow assumptions and@convinced myself I knew them in their entirety.

group_1.textLeft: *Sniff*  Ugh...I'm so...stupid...

group_1.textRight: ...Is that what came to mind when you saw@Mikage and Sudachi?
If so, you've done well. You demonstrated@fine conduct.

group_1.textLeft: *Sniff* *Sob* But...my parents...

group_1.textRight: Well, you can wallow in pity for as@long as you want.
You made a grave mistake in the past,@and you regret it.
Despite your remorse, however, you unconsciously@made those same judgments again.
The fact that you're aware and reflecting@on it is a good thing,
but you also have to recognize that if you don't@change your ways, there's no point in any of this.

group_1.textLeft: If I don't change my ways...there's no point...

group_1.textRight: ...Say, Lady Nayuta.
Are you aware of the saying, "marking the boat@to find the sword"?

group_1.textLeft: ...I am.
It means one has become so strung up in tradition@that they fail to notice how the times have changed.
What does that have to do with this?@It's just a saying.

group_1.textRight: Yes, it is just a saying.
But while it's not exactly a fundamental truth,@such behavior does occur all too often among the@elderly.

group_1.textLeft: I fail to understand why you're telling me@this now.
It has nothing to do with my situation.

group_1.textRight: ...Are you familiar with the fable that the@saying originated from?

group_1.textLeft: That...I am not.

group_1.narration: "Once upon a time, there was a man sailing on a boat@who dropped his treasured sword in the river."
"In a snap decision, he chose to leave@a mark on the boat to indicate the place where@he dropped it, so that he could later retrieve it@from the river."
"He must have been in a rush."
"He carved a mark on the hull of the boat@when he should have etched it on a map."
"Marking the point where it fell on a moving ship@was useless in helping him retrieve his sword."

group_1.textRight: ...It's the story of a very thoughtless man.

group_1.textLeft: *Giggle* He seems quite scatterbrained.

group_1.textRight: But I didn't tell you this story to make you laugh.
I want you to consider how this anecdote gained@the meaning it does.
What is the sword you lost, Lady Nayuta?
Where did you leave your mark?
How has the world around you changed,@and what are the old ways you still cling to?

group_1.textLeft: ...There are countless swords I have lost.
The ship is always moving forward,@and I am changing along with it.
But the river is flowing as well, and@everyone else is changing too.
Everything is undergoing constant transformation.
I was too careless to notice the ways@the people around me have changed,
let alone the changes in my situation.
I am stubborn, just as everyone has said.

group_1.textRight: It's not too late for you to realize that. In terms of@salvaging relationships, you can start with somebody@familiar to you...
